Python Solution: Run Time - 759 ms

class Solution:
    def maxArea(self, height: List[int]) -> int:       
        minHeight = 0
        res = 0
        maxVal = 0
        lenHeight = len(height)        
        j = lenHeight - 1 
        k = j  
        l = 0        
        for i in range(lenHeight):                           
                if height[l] > height[j]:
                    minHeight = height[j]
                else:
                    minHeight = height[l]
                res = minHeight * k                
                maxVal = max(maxVal,res)   
                if height[j] < height[l]:            
                    j -= 1                   
                else:
                    l += 1             
                k -= 1                
        return maxVal

Why the two pointer approach works(in simple words): We take two pointers i and j starting at the extremes of the array and keep moving i to right and j to the left. if `height[i] < height[j]` - In brute force we would have calculated `(i,j-1), (i,j-2).. ` - Since `height[i]` is lesser, even though the values of `height[j-1], height[j-2]..` are more, we are limited by `height[i] ` - But width keeps decreasing as we move j to the left fixing i, so area also keeps decreasing Same applies for other case `height[i] > height[j]`

    `class Solution:
        def maxArea(self, height: List[int]) -> int:
            left = 0
            right = len(height) - 1
            water = 0

            while True:
                # the least number is the multiplier
                multipler = height[left] if height[left] < height[right] else height[right]

                #calculate the water contained and update 
                tmp_water = (right-left) * multipler
                if tmp_water > water: water = tmp_water

                if(height[left] < height[right]): left += 1
                else: right -= 1

                if(left >= right): break
        
        return water
`

My approach was iterating through all the possible columns height[i] throughout the array, and for each one iterating through the indices of the array once from 0 to i and again from i+1 to height.length - 1 to get the index of the 2nd column j. 
 I only considered the pairs (i,j) such that h[i] <= h[j] without loss of generality. 
These two iterations were used in order to ensure we start at the farthest possible column in the respective direction of the concerned column i and iterate towards i, breaking out of the loop whenever h[j] >= h[i] since the "area of a container" in this case is simply min{h[i],h[j]} * |j-i| = h[i] * |j-i|. Hence a larger absolute difference between j and i where h[j] >= h[i] produces a maximum container area for such a value of h[i].
Despite the fact that two for loops for the iteration inside the outside index counter loop were used and the overall time complexity may seem like a brute force O(N^2) on surface level,

[@LeetCode](/LeetCode) official solution leads to "Time Limit Exceeded" in Java.

This is actually an interesting problem, which can be easily solved in `O(n)` time using `O(1)` space. 

The key idea is to use two pointers.
We initialize `left = 0` and `right = n-1` (n=the number of elements in the array).
Now arises the following three cases:
`1) height[left] > height[right]`
`2) height[right] > height[left]`
`3) height[left] == height[right]`

`CASE 1 :`
Decrement `right` by 1.
The reason behind is that the maximum water that the container starting at left and ending at right can hold, is `min(height[left] , height[right])*(right-left)`. If we increment `left`, then it is guaranteed that the minimum of both the heights will not go above `height[right]` , however the difference `(right-left)` will get reduced. As a result the maximum water holding capacity will either remain constant or decrease.
Here we will not increment left and decrement right simultaneously as we may miss a better solution.

`CASE 2 :`
Increment `left` by 1.
The reason is similar to the previous one, as decrementing `right` pointer either decreases the result or keeps it constant.

`CASE 3 :`
Simultaneously increment `left` and decrement `right`.
Here if we either increment `left` or decrement `right`, then again the minimum of the two heights does not increases. It either decreases or remains the same. The only option remaining is to do both simultaneously.

NOTE : After every iteration do not forget to update the answer as in
 `ans = max(ans , min(height[left] , height[right]) * (right-left))`
It's not a medium problem at all. It's too easy

[@LeetCode](/LeetCode) official solution leads to "Time Limit Exceeded" in Java.

This is actually an interesting problem, which can be easily solved in `O(n)` time using `O(1)` space. 

The key idea is to use two pointers.
We initialize `left = 0` and `right = n-1` (n=the number of elements in the array).
Now arises the following three cases:
`1) height[left] > height[right]`
`2) height[right] > height[left]`
`3) height[left] == height[right]`

`CASE 1 :`
Decrement `right` by 1.
The reason behind is that the maximum water that the container starting at left and ending at right can hold, is `min(height[left] , height[right])*(right-left)`. If we increment `left`, then it is guaranteed that the minimum of both the heights will not go above `height[right]` , however the difference `(right-left)` will get reduced. As a result the maximum water holding capacity will either remain constant or decrease.
Here we will not increment left and decrement right simultaneously as we may miss a better solution.

`CASE 2 :`
Increment `left` by 1.
The reason is similar to the previous one, as decrementing `right` pointer either decreases the result or keeps it constant.

`CASE 3 :`
Simultaneously increment `left` and decrement `right`.
Here if we either increment `left` or decrement `right`, then again the minimum of the two heights does not increases. It either decreases or remains the same. The only option remaining is to do both simultaneously.

NOTE : After every iteration do not forget to update the answer as in
 `ans = max(ans , min(height[left] , height[right]) * (right-left))`
It's not a medium problem at all. It's too easy

O(N) beats 97.71 in time. Simple python solution

 
    `class Solution:
        def maxArea(self, height: List[int]) -> int:
            left = 0
            right = len(height) - 1
            water = 0

            while True:
                # the least number is the multiplier
                multipler = height[left] if height[left] < height[right] else height[right]

                #calculate the water contained and update 
                tmp_water = (right-left) * multipler
                if tmp_water > water: water = tmp_water

                if(height[left] < height[right]): left += 1
                else: right -= 1

                if(left >= right): break
        
        return water
`
